questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not an anticholinergic drug?
questions.explanation:
Amphetamine is not an anticholinergic (parasympatholytics) drug. It is an indirectly acting 
sympathomimetic drug used as a CNS stimulant. Parasympatholytic drugs are classified as: Class 
Drugs Muscarinic antagonis 
ts AtropineScopolamineHomatr 
opineTropicamideIpratropiu 
m, TiotropiumDarifenacin, S 
olifenacinPirenzipine, Telenzi 
pineGlycopyrrolateUmeclidin 
ium Nicotinic antagonists 
Nnantagonists 
TrimethaphanHexamethoniu 
mMecamylamine Nmantagonists 
Depolarizing 
SuxamethoniumDecamethon 
ium Non-depolarizing 
PancuroniumVecuroniumRoc 
uroniumd-tubocurarineMivac 
uriumAtracurium

questions.question:
Question 2: What is the scientific name of this plant whose roots & leaves were historically used in 
the treatment of asthma?
questions.explanation:
The above plant is Datura stramonium, also called Jamestown or Jimsonweed. The active ingredient in Datura stramonium includes anticholinergic alkaloids such as atropine, 
scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. These were helpful in relieving the symptoms associated with 
asthma via inhibition of M3 receptors on bronchi, leading to a decrease in bronchospasm and 
tracheobronchial secretions.

questions.question:
Question 3: 112 
Sold by @itachibot On administration of atropine, which of the following effects is unlikely?
questions.explanation:
120 
Sold by @itachibot Atropine does not cause increased bowel sounds. It decreases the amplitude and frequency of 
peristalsis, resulting in decreased bowel sounds. Peristalsis suppression due to atropine is incomplete because of the additional control of 
peristalsis by local reflexes in the enteric nervous system and involvement of other 
neurotransmitters like 5-HT, encephalin, dopamine in peristalsis. Actions of atropine: • Mydriasis - by blocking the contraction of sphincter pupillae muscle • Decreased secretions from salivary glands and lacrimal glands - by blocking M1 & M3 
receptors • Tachycardia - due to its vagolytic activity at M2 receptor • Decreased sweating - by inhibiting sympathetic cholinergic supply to sweat glands which makes 
the skin hot and dry (atropine fever).

questions.question:
Question 4: While treating a patient with acute myocardial infarction, an abnormal rhythm was noted on 
the ECG. The senior resident decides to administer atropine to control this. What was the 
likely rhythm observed in the patient?
questions.explanation:
Atropine is indicated in acute myocardial infarction when it is accompanied by sinus bradycardia 
due to excessive vagal tone. It is seen commonly in inferior or posterior wall myocardial 
infarction. The dosage of atropine has to be carefully adjusted when used in a patient with myocardial 
infarction. If the dose is too low it will aggravate the bradycardia by action on presynaptic 
M1 receptors. If the dose is too high it will cause significant tachycardia and aggravate the 
condition by competitive inhibition of postsynaptic M2 receptors.

questions.question:
Question 5: You administer atropine at a dose of 0.5 mg IV to a patient with symptomatic bradycardia. 
What would be the effect on heart rate?
questions.explanation:
Atropine at average clinical doses of 0.4-0.6 mg administered parenterally results in transient 
bradycardia followed by tachycardia. Parasympathetic postganglionic nerve terminals in the SA node contain presynaptic M1 receptors. 
These receptors normally inhibit the release of ACh. Therefore stimulation of these receptors 
decreases the release of ACh causing tachycardia. Inhibition of these receptors increases ACh 
causing bradycardia. Atropine initially blocks these presynaptic M1 receptors. This increases the amount of ACh 
released at the SA node and causes bradycardia. Then, the progressive increase in the atropine 
concentration blocks the postsynaptic M2 receptors on the SA node (decreasing the ACh release) 
decreasing the parasympathetic tone, thereby causing tachycardia.

questions.question:
Question 6: A delirious child was rushed to the ER with a history of ingestion of an unknown plant. On 
examination, his pulse rate was 150 beats per minute, and his skin was warm and dry. Pupils 
were dilated and bowel sounds were sluggish. Which of the following toxidromes is likely to 
be responsible for the symptoms in this child?
questions.explanation:
121 
Sold by @itachibot Mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth, atropine fever (warm, hot skin) and delirium are classical 
symptoms of anticholinergic overdose following the ingestion of plants that contain belladonna 
alkaloids. Physostigmine is the drug of choice for the treatment of atropine and belladonna poisoning. Option B: Sympathomimetics can cause mydriasis and tachycardia. Hyperthermia can be seen 
secondary to increased agitation and aggressive movements. However, delirium is rare and bowel 
sounds would be normal or increased in sympathomimetic toxidromes. Option C: Opioid overdose results in decreased bowel sounds but other symptoms are not seen. Option D: In sedative-hypnotic toxidrome, CNS depression and reduced bowel sounds are seen. 
But it does not cause tachycardia or change in pupil diameter.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following would you use in the treatment of atropine toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Atropine toxicity is treated with physostigmine, a reversible anticholinesterase agent. Physostigmine acts by decreasing the breakdown of acetylcholine, and it also overcomes the 
competitive blockade of atropine in all muscarinic receptors. 122 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: You are monitoring a patient being treated with atropine for alleged consumption of an 
organophosphate compound. Suddenly he develops marked excitement and claims to see his 
late wife sitting next to him. All of the following can be used in the management of this 
patient except?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features of marked excitement and hallucinations are seen in atropine toxicity. 
Chlorpromazine should be avoided in patients with atropine toxicity. Chlorpromazine is a low potency typical antipsychotic having high anticholinergic 
activity. Administering phenothiazines like chlorpromazine will worsen atropine toxicity. Option A: Physostigmine is indicated as first-line therapy for atropine intoxication Option B and D: Benzodiazepines can be used when marked excitement is present to calm down 
the patient 123 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: Atropine is indicated in all of the following poisonings except  
.
questions.explanation:
Endrin is an organochloride pesticide that causes neurotoxicity. There is no antidote available 
and only symptomatic treatment is done. Parathion and TIK20 are organophosphates and baygon is a combination of organophosphate and 
carbamate. For all of these, atropine is the drug of choice.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following describes the mechanism of mydriasis due to the instillation of a 
muscarinic antagonist?

options.a: Contraction of the sphincter pupillae of the iris
options.b: Paralysis of the dilator pupillae muscles of the iris
options.c: Contraction of the dilator pupillae muscles of the iris
options.d: Paralysis of the sphincter pupillae of the iris

questions.explanation:
Mydriatic action of a muscarinic antagonist is due to the paralysis of the sphincter 
pupillae (circular) muscle of the iris. In the iris, miosis occurs due to the constriction of the pupillary sphincter muscles and mydriasis 
is due to the contraction of the dilator pupillae (radial) muscles. They counter-balance each other. When muscarinic antagonists are instilled, the pupillary sphincter muscle is paralyzed, causing 
mydriasis due to the unopposed contraction of the dilator pupillae muscle. Adrenergic alpha agonists also cause mydriasis, but by mediating the contraction of the dilator 
pupillae muscle of iris. Parasympatholytic drugs are classified as: Class 
Drugs Muscarinic antagonis 
ts AtropineScopolamineHomatr 
opineTropicamideIpratropiu 
m, TiotropiumDarifenacin, S 
olifenacinPirenzipine, Telenzi 
pineGlycopyrrolateUmeclidin 
ium Nicotinic antagonists 
Nnantagonists 
TrimethaphanHexamethoniu 
mMecamylamine Nmantagonists 
Depolarizing 
SuxamethoniumDecamethon 
ium Non-depolarizing 
PancuroniumVecuroniumRoc 
uroniumd-tubocurarineMivac 
uriumAtracurium

questions.question: Question 11: To achieve which of the following states will you use phenylephrine instead of atropine?
questions.explanation:
Atropine is substituted by phenylephrine in situations where mydriasis is required without 
cycloplegia, like in fundoscopy. Phenylephrine, an alpha 1 agonist, acts on the radial muscle (dilator pupillae) of the iris and 
causes isolated mydriasis. It has no cycloplegic action because sympathetic receptors are present 
only on the iris and not on the ciliary body. 124 
Sold by @itachibot Atropine has both mydriatic and cycloplegic action, which is required for refraction testing. In elderly people who have a low ciliary tone, phenylephrine is preferred as a mydriatic. This is 
because other anticholinergics can precipitate or aggravate glaucoma by relaxation of the ciliary 
body and altering the forces acting on trabecular meshwork for aqueous outflow. Atropine, cyclopentolate, and tropicamide are antimuscarinics that are available for ophthalmic 
use and cause cycloplegia to a variable extent. This cycloplegia/paralysis of accommodation occurs 
due to their parasympatholytic action, which decreases the tone of the ciliary body.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is a short-acting mydriatic that you can use for performing a 
fundoscopy?
questions.explanation:
Tropicamide is a short-acting mydriatic used in fundoscopy. It has a rapid onset (20-40 minutes) and a brief duration of action (3-6 hours). The cycloplegia 
produced by tropicamide is unreliable and insignificant. It is indicated for fundoscopy and 
refraction testing in adults who have a relatively low ciliary tone when compared to children. Atropine, which produces complete cycloplegia, is preferred in children as they have a higher 
ciliary tone. Atropine is usually preferred over other mydriatics for accurate refractory error 
testing because of reliable cycloplegia. However, it can also precipitate an acute attack of 
glaucoma and should not be used in patients with glaucoma.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 70-year-old diabetic patient presents to the OPD for diabetic retinopathy screening. Why 
would you prefer phenylephrine over other anticholinergic drugs as a mydriatic agent before 
performing fundoscopy?

options.a: High ciliary tone in elderly patients
options.c: Phenylephrine can decrease ciliary tone in elderly patients

questions.explanation:
Phenylephrine is preferred in elderly people as other anticholinergics can precipitate or aggravate 
glaucoma. Elderly people have low ciliary tone, and phenylephrine does not alter the tone of the ciliary 
body. Other anticholinergics cause relaxation of the ciliary body and alter the forces acting on 
trabecular meshwork for aqueous outflow.

questions.question:
Question 14: 115 
Sold by @itachibot A young man with a history of motion sickness presents to your OPD with upcoming plans for 
a road trip. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?

options.b: Ondansetran one night before and also before trip

questions.explanation:
Scopolamine (Hyoscine) transdermal patch is the most appropriate treatment for motion sickness 
before a trip. It should be applied behind the ear about 5-6 hours before the journey, and gives protection for 
around 72 hours against motion sickness, after which the patch can be replaced if necessary. Scopolamine is also used for narcoanalysis as it causes sedation and amnesia. Dimenhydrinate is a first-generation antihistamine that can also be used in motion sickness. 
Although dimenhydrinate may have equal efficacy it is not preferred because of its sedating 
properties. 125 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine?
questions.explanation:
Pirenzepine is used for treating gastric ulcers. It is a selective M1 anticholinergic drug. It 
decreases gastric acid secretions at doses that have little effect on salivation or heart rate.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 32-year-old woman diagnosed with diarrhoea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome 
presented to the casualty with severe abdominal pain. She was prescribed a drug that exerts a 
direct spasmolytic effect on the smooth muscles of the gastrointestinal tract. Which drug 
could it be?
questions.explanation:
Dicyclomine is a weak muscarinic receptor antagonist with non-specific direct spasmolytic effects 
on the smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract. Other options: Option B: Scopolamine exerts spasmolytic activity indirectly through its antimuscarinic action. It 
is not preferred due to its adverse effects like drowsiness, dryness, and blurred vision. Option C and D: Galantamine and rivastigmine are central cholinesterase inhibitors and do not 
possess spasmolytic activity.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following agents shows M3 receptor selectivity?
questions.explanation:
M3 receptor selectivity is shown by solifenacin and darifenacin. Oxybutynin and trospium do not show any selectivity. Tolterodine has a more specific action on 
the urinary bladder but subtype selectivity is absent.

questions.question:
Question 18: Among the following antimuscarinic drugs used in the treatment of overactive bladder, which 
one shows direct spasmolytic activity on smooth muscles?
questions.explanation:
Oxybutynin is an antimuscarinic drug indicated in the overactive bladder that also exerts a direct 
spasmolytic action on the smooth muscles of the bladder. Direct spasmolytic activity is the direct smooth muscle relaxation effect independent of relaxation 
caused by antimuscarinic action. The most important adverse effects caused by the use of muscarinic antagonists for an overactive 
bladder are xerostomia (most common reason for discontinuation), blurred vision, and GI side 
effects like constipation and dyspepsia (due to blockade of M1, M2 & M3). Drowsiness, 
dizziness, and confusion can also occur. Tolterodine, darifenacin, and solifenacin are antimuscarinic agents but they do not have the 
additional direct antispasmodic effect.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following is not true regarding the effects of muscarinic antagonists on the 
urinary bladder?

options.c: Lowers the frequency of bladder contractions

questions.explanation:
Muscarinic antagonists increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on the detrusor. This 
results in the relaxation of the bladder. 126 
Sold by @itachibot Effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder: • Lowers intravesicular pressure • Increases bladder capacity • Lowers the frequency of bladder contractions • Alters bladder sensation during filling

questions.question:
Question 20: After suffering from a stroke, a middle-aged patient was diagnosed with overactive bladder 
due to detrusor instability. Which of the following drugs is not useful in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Duloxetine is not useful in detrusor instability. It is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine 
reuptake inhibitor that is efficacious in stress urinary incontinence. It is also indicated 
in depression, fibromyalgia, and neuropathic pain. Muscarinic antagonists are useful in this case. They increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 
receptors on detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder. The effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder are: • Lowering of intravesicular pressure • Increases bladder capacity • Lower the frequency of bladder contractions • Alter bladder sensation during filling

questions.question:
Question 21: In a patient with overactive bladder, what is the most common reason for him to discontinue 
treatment with muscarinic antagonists?
questions.explanation:
Xerostomia is the most common reason for the discontinuation of muscarinic antagonists in 
overactive bladder. The most important adverse effects caused by the use of muscarinic antagonists for an overactive 
bladder are xerostomia, blurred vision, and GI side effects like constipation and dyspepsia (due to 
blockade of M1, M2 & M3). Drowsiness, dizziness, and confusion can also occur.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following has selective action on M1 and M3 receptors?
questions.explanation:
Tiotropium has a selective action on M1 and M3 receptors. Tiotropium binds to all M1, M2 and M3 receptors. However, it dissociates slower from M1 and M3 
receptors as compared to M2. This shows it has a higher affinity towards M1 and M3 receptors. Ipratropium and atropine methonitrate do not have any subtype selectivity on muscarinic 
receptors. Inhibition of mucociliary clearance by atropine results in the accumulation of lower airway 
secretions and the formation of mucus plugs. However, tiotropium and ipratropium have 
minimum interference with mucociliary clearance when compared to atropine, and the incidence 127 
Sold by @itachibot of mucus plugs is also less.

questions.question: Question 23: In which of the following patients is the use of trospium contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
The use of trospium is contraindicated in urinary retention. It is an antimuscarinic agent and can 
worsen urinary retention. Muscarinic antagonists are contraindicated in urinary tract obstruction and in benign prostatic 
hyperplasia (or used with extreme caution). Bronchial asthma, hypertension, and peptic ulcer disease are not the contraindications for the use 
of trospium.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Glycopyrrolate usually does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome. It is a quaternary 
amine compound and lipid insoluble. Therefore, glycopyrrolate does not cross the blood-brain 
barrier. Non-depolarising skeletal muscle relaxants are used in anesthesia. Neostigmine along with 
glycopyrrolate are used for reversal of this neuromuscular block. Glycopyrrolate blocks the 
peripheral muscarinic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine levels after the 
administration of neostigmine, without causing unwanted central anticholinergic effects. Peripheral and central anticholinergic syndromes are reactions due to either overdose or any 
unusual reaction to the usage of drugs like atropine and other muscarinic agents, phenothiazines, 
antihistamines, and tricyclic antidepressants Option B: Atropine is a tertiary compound that can cross the blood-brain barrier and cause central 
anticholinergic syndrome. Option C and D: Some of the first-generation antihistamines and tricyclic antidepressants have 
significant anticholinergic activity and can cause central anticholinergic syndrome.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is most commonly used for narcoanalysis?
questions.explanation:
The most commonly used drug in narcoanalysis is pentothal sodium (thiopentone). Other drugs used in narcoanalysis are sodium amytal and secobarbital. Scopolamine hydrochloride was also used in narcoanalysis during World War II. It was popularly 
known as the 'lie detector'. The amnesic and depressant actions of scopolamine are due to the 
inhibition of the brain cholinergic system. It would put the subject off guard in case of sustained 
interrogation and sleep deprivation, eventually forcing the truth out. 128 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 26: Inhibitory effect on mucociliary clearance is minimal with which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Both ipratropium and tiotropium have a minimal inhibitory effect on mucociliary clearance when 
compared to atropine. Inhibition of mucociliary clearance by atropine results in accumulation of 
lower airway secretions and formation of mucus plugs. 129 
Sold by @itachibot Sympatholytics
